Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 05:08PM Sherrie1964 wrote: Hi everyone, Just checking in with you all.  I've done 8 treatments so far and I've noticed that my breast feels a little hot afterwards, but it quickly dissipates.  I've been applying Aloe and some other cream samples my doc gave me twice a day.  I have sensitive skin so I'm expecting a reaction at some point.  I hope being proactive with the creams helps to lessen it.  TJW, Ivy and Windalina - I have been considering asking for the anti-depressant.  It seems like whenever I get really down in the dumps, somehow I end up having several really good days and then I think well maybe I really don't need it.  I'm not sure what I should do. TJW - I'm sorry you are having these side-effects from what is supposed to be a cake-walk compared to chemo.   That is depressing, but hang in there and stay strong....this too shall pass.  I'll be thinking of you. Happy rads everyone - Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 06:00AM Sherrie1964 wrote: Kim, I have been having hot flashes at night which wake me up about the same time every night.  I am also scheduled to start tamoxifen at the beginning of the year.  I've read that the effexor or wellbutrin works wonders for many ladies.  Are you getting your hot flashes at night only?  I am taking Ativan right now and it helps with the sleep issue.  I hope everyone has a WONDERFUL Thanksgiving.  I am very thankful for having you ladies to talk to! Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 03:06AM Sherrie1964 wrote: Hi Everyone,  Haven't posted here for a while. I just went back to work Monday, so it's been a long and tiring week.  I just finished 15 of 30 treatments yesterday.  Halfway through!!  I'm so looking forward to being done.  Skin seems to holding up well so far.  I've been using Fruit of the Earth 100% Aloe Gel.  The doc also gave me a couple of samples which i've been alternating with the Aloe.  They are Jean's Cream (very nice, but expensive), and Alra (this one is also very nice and much more reasonably priced).  Once I'm done with this, it will be on to the tamoxifen.  At least that's what the plan is right now.  My insurance company offers a cheek swab test to determine whether or not you metabolize tamoxifen effectively.  I will be doing that.  Traveler56, I'm so sorry about your friend.  My heart and prayers go out to you and her family.  Best - Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 06:11PM - edited Nov 4, 2008 06:12PM by Sherrie1964 Hi Everyone, I will also be starting radiation in November.  I have my simulation on the 11th.  I'll be doing the whole breast radiation 33 treatments with a boost.  I am having my last TC chemo tomorrow and can't wait until I'm done......I too am hoping that the fatigue with the rads will not match the fatigue from chemo. I'm thinking that I will try to schedule my treatments for in the morning before I go into work and just get it done.  Traveler56, I also drive about 30 miles to work (60 miles roundtrip) and the cancer center I go to is 5 minutes away from work.  I have been very emotional lately - this journey seems like it will never end.  You are all in my thoughts and prayers that we get through this leg of our treatment with as little discomfort as possible!!  Thanks for all of your suggestions! Otter - thanks for the tips on the LE therapist.  I started having some pain in my forearm and the  inside of my upper arm after treatment #2.  The APRN thought she felt some cording and suggested I do some good stretching after treatment #3 which I have been doing.  The stretching makes the pain subside and the upper arm pain is pretty much gone, but I still get some in the lower arm when it tightens up and I flex my wrist up.  I will see oncologist tomorrow before Tx #4 and will see what she has to say.    Sherrie (edited for some spelling errors)
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2008 04:49PM Sherrie1964 wrote: Hi all, Been on the boards some but haven't been posting much lately.  Since I've been back to work,  the fatigue has really set in.  I basically get home, eat dinner and go to bed.....  The good news is that I had 25 of 30 treatments today.  I will start my boosts tomorrow and be done on Christmas Eve!  My skin has held up pretty well, some redness around the edges of the area being treated. Ivy - I will talk to my Onc in January about the antidepressent.  It's good to know you're experiencing improvement with it.  Thanks. Merry Christmas everyone! Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 05:34AM Sherrie1964 wrote: Hey traveler56 - congrats on nearing the finish line! I had my simulation last week and have had two treatments to date.  So far, so good. I know that some lose and some gain weight during chemo.  I gained and was hoping to start working on that during rads, but the techs told me not to lose or gain during treatment as this impacts planned treatment.  Anyone else hear this?    Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 04:52PM Sherrie1964 wrote: Bethany - thanks  and yes, I will ask the doctor when I see him this week.  I really want to start back in on working out so I hope it's not a problem.  I've also been home on disability while on chemo and planning on going back on Dec 1st and I know that once I'm more active that I will drop at least a few pounds! HensonChi - It sounds like you're feeling the way I did a couple of weeks ago when I had my last chemo.  I was glad that I was done, but was feeling down about having to start yet another leg of treatment.  I'm still anemic and my wbc's are below normal.  It seems at times that this is all never ending.....but chin up right - we just gotta do what we gotta do and get throught this nightmare! I still have off taste buds from the chemo and I'm probably too new to rads to have any side effects yet.  It's been almost two weeks since my last chemo and the metal taste has improved significantly.  I hope it continues cause it would be so nice to have normal taste buds again. Sherrie
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 01:13PM Sherrie1964 wrote: LuAnn, I'm new to the boards and don't feel that I even have a place to comment........I don't mean this in a negative way but you are so right.  I (an many) cannot truly understand what it means to be in your shoes.  I have to say that when all the hype started up about breast cancer awareness in October this year, I wasn't very excited.  My mother was diagnosed at 60 (when I was 25) and it was devastating.  I have since took part in any awareness campaign that I have been able, from donations to walks, etc..... I thought I understood everything about breast cancer.  It really wasn't until my diagnosis this past May that I have learned so much; more than I ever wanted to know.  I think for most, to see and truly understand all the realties is too painful.  Then again, to say you are a supporter for bc research and a cure and not really understand all the facets of the disease and the depths to which it impacts people is sloppy, unfair and just plain inaccurate.  I think the pretty pink stuff started out as a way to bring more attention to the issue, which was great.  Now I would venture to say that the pink stuff has just really caught on and has become more of a marketing tactic to drive profits.  I really can't say, cause I haven't done my homework, but as a donor I want to know just how much of those sales are truly going to the cause.  At any rate, in our world today attention is good, so I'm at least glad that breast cancer stands out as an issue nowadays. One thing I do feel confident about saying is that YOU are truly amazing.  I have been reading all the support you offer to the women on this board and you are an invaluable resource to them.  Another thing is that if I ever have an opportunity to speak in a public forum on breastcancer awareness, I will not forget to tell the whole story.......you are right.  If we're going to talk about breast cancer, let's talk about all of it, not just the stuff that's less painful to swallow. God bless and stay strong! Sherrie
Posts.Title: Long, but need your opinion LuAnnH mom2acat

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2012 08:41PM Sherrie1964 wrote: Hello, I had a fibroadenoma about the size of an egg removed when I was 18.  I remember there were times when it was very painful and other times when I felt nothing at all.  You absolutely should follow up and don't stop until you feel absolutely comfortable with the answers you receive from your doctors.
Posts.Title: Fibroadenoma is larger, painful rocksteady14 Sommer43

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 01:43PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:56AM by Sherrie1964 mje123 - As everyone says, it's a very personal decision.  I think my score was either a 21 or 22 and my onc said anything over 18 would mean chemo. From my perspective, 3% doesn't seem that high unless you're on the wrong side of the statistic.  So to me, that was a big enough difference.  Somebody has to be in that 3% and I wanted to do everything I could to try and not be.  It's true, you can have chemo and still have a recurrence; but I knew I couldn't live with the "what if" if it happened to me.  I hope this helps. Sherrie
Posts.Title: Oncotype Score of 21 - Not Sure About Chemo? mje123 mje123

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 05:01PM - edited Nov 8, 2011 05:01PM by Sherrie1964 This is an interesting topic.  I was diagnosed with a rare autoimmune skin disease just days after finishing breast cancer treatment.  I started having the skin symptoms just after the BC diagnosis. I was on several different medications for over a year and was not able to start my Tamoxifen for 6 months after treatment ended.  Things are pretty much back to "normal" now but it was a pretty exhausting couple of years; managing all the doctor appointments and medications, not to mention just plain having to educate every doctor I came into contact with on my disease.  I still have times when I feel very isolated as a result of my diagnoses.  Interestingly though, I'm much more eager to discuss my breast cancer with others rather than my autoimmune disease.  Sherrie
